{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3635083,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-24T17:08:28.967Z","cooked":"

Continuing the discussion from 1323 - 2025 Tech Binder:

Herringbone bevel??
What was the modeling software and technique you used?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-05-24T17:12:23.597Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":118,"reads":576,"readers_count":575,"score":820.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502343,"topic_slug":"herringbone-bevel-gear-design-by-sam-carlberg","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/1323-2025-tech-binder/500435/173","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"1323 - 2025 Tech Binder","clicks":104},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/1323-2025-tech-binder/500435/175","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"1323 - 2025 Tech Binder","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/herringbone-bevel-gear-design-by-sam-carlberg/502343/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3635096,"name":"Sam Carlberg","username":"SamCarlberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/samcarlberg/{size}/207684_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-24T17:34:59.632Z","cooked":"

I use onshape as my CAD program. The gears were generated using the Gear Lab featurescript, which lets you generate pairs of gears [1] and the script handles the spacing. All I had to do was plug in the parameters and design the yoke to give some breathing room around the gears and everything just meshed. I did end up taking physical measurements to make the spacers to get the inner passthrough gears at the correct positions, but that was more because I got lazy and didn’t want to CAD those parts in an assembly context.

This is what the gear lab featurescript looks like. (You can ignore the bore; I was experimenting with that feature and it really isn’t good. I made a separate feature to get a correct-sized bore to fit a 1.125" bearing)

image1920×1073 126 KB

And the part studio with the differential gears + yoke. Only one of the two input gears is modeled, since it’s just mirrored to the other side in the final assembly.

image1920×1073 109 KB

[1] Technically, new gears are generated to mesh with an existing gear at a certain axle angle and bevel angle.

Gear lab is a little annoying to use. Changing a gear configuration (such as tooth length) may also regenerate the entire part, which can break dependent features and force sketches to be redefined. Holes and “remove” extrudes can sometimes result in zero-thickness geometry; fortunately, the slicer will eliminate it, but the models are incorrect.

The face inside the highlighted ring is zero-thickness

image1920×1073 124 KB

If a hole extends beyond the opposite face (or even is an “up to next” end instead of blind), it may also generate a solid cylinder past that face that the slicer doesn’t remove. Maybe the gear designer featurescript linked in that forum post is less buggy; I haven’t used it yet, but I might end up trying it out if I get fed up with gear lab
